title: Effective Readbacks
content: Readbacks should include the essential elements: who, what, where, when, and critical values. Don't just parrot—demonstrate understanding. If unsure, say so. A questioning readback is better than an incorrect confident one.

scenario.story: Control instructs: 'Unit 7, reduce main pump flow to 450 GPM over the next 10 minutes.' The operator responds: 'Copy, reducing flow.' They begin reducing flow on Unit 8's auxiliary pump immediately.

options.A: The readback was adequate—they confirmed the action
options.B: The incomplete readback allowed three errors to go undetected
options.C: Control should have been more specific

scenario.explanation: The readback omitted unit number (wrong unit), pump identification (wrong pump), target value, and timeframe (immediate vs. gradual). A complete readback—'Unit 7, reducing main pump flow to 450 GPM over 10 minutes'—would have revealed all errors before action.
